In most cases, patients do not experience any symptoms or complications due to NSVT.  3. Aflutter: Atrial flutter occurs when the atria of the heart beat too quickly or chaotically. Aflutter is a subtype of SVTs and can be diagnosed by an electrocardiogram (ECG).  4. Tachycardia: Tachycardia is an abnormal resting heart rate greater than 100 beats per minute. Tachycardia can be a symptom of an underlying medical condition, and it can lead to complications like fainting or low blood pressure.  5. VTach: Ventricular tachycardia is a fast heartbeat originating from the ventricles, which are the lower chambers of the heart. VTach can lead to life-threatening complications if not treated promptly.  6. Trigeminy: Trigeminy is a pattern of three consecutive beats, where two beats are normal, and one is premature. Trigeminy is a subtype of ectopic beats, which are abnormal heart rhythm originating from somewhere other than the sinus node.  7. Bigeminy: Bigeminy is a pattern of two consecutive beats, where one is normal, and the other is premature. Bigeminy is also a subtype of ectopic beats.  8. Supraventricular: Supraventricular refers to any arrhythmia originating from above the ventricles of the heart. This includes sinus node tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and other types of tachycardia.  9. Vasovagal: Vasovagal syncope is a sudden drop in blood pressure and heart rate due to the stimulation of the vagus nerve. Vasovagal is common in people with underlying medical conditions, such as dehydration or heart disease.  10. AVNRT: AV nodal reentrant tachycardia is a type of SVT that occurs in the atrioventricular node. AVNRT can cause palpitations, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.  11. Fibrillations: Fibrillations are rapid, irregular contractions of the heart muscles. Fibrillations can indicate underlying medical conditions, such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular fibrillation.  12. Arrhythmia: Arrhythmia is an abnormal heart rhythm caused by electrical impulses that don't follow the usual pattern. Arrhythmias can have various causes, including structural heart disease, electrolyte imbalances, or medications.  13. PVC: Premature ventricular contractions are an abnormal heart rhythm originating from the ventricles. PVCs can occur randomly, and they usually do not cause any symptoms or complications.  14. Afib: Atrial fibrillation is a type of arrhythmia characterized by rapid, irregular contractions of the atria. This can lead to blood clots, stroke, or heart failure.  15. Junctional: Junctional rhythms are abnormal heart rhythms originating from the atrioventricular node. Junctional rhythms can cause symptoms like shortness of breath, chest discomfort, or lightheadedness.
